summary: This document is a chain of internal email correspondence from 2019 regarding travel approval requests for federal prosecutors and investigators to conduct interviews in West Palm Beach, Florida, and Los Angeles, California, as part of the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein (case 2018R01618). The emails detail logistical planning for victim interviews and the need to reserve hotel conference rooms for these meetings.

events.title: Planned Interview in West Palm Beach
events.description: Prosecutors requested travel approval for an interview to be conducted in West Palm Beach on this date, requiring a hotel conference room.

events.title: Planned Victim Interview in Los Angeles
events.description: Prosecutors requested travel approval for a victim interview in Los Angeles, tentatively scheduled for a Wednesday-Friday timeframe.

events.title: Meetings and Interviews in West Palm Beach
events.description: Prosecutors requested travel approval for approximately three days of meetings and interviews with victims in West Palm Beach, Florida.

events.title: Travel for Meetings and Interviews in Florida
events.description: Prosecutor S requested permission to travel for approximately three days for meetings and interviews in West Palm Beach, Florida, for the Epstein case.

events.title: Travel for Florida Meetings
events.description: Prosecutors requested travel approval for two days of meetings and interviews in West Palm Beach and/or Fort Lauderdale, Florida, for the Epstein investigation.

keyFacts: The document references the federal criminal case 'United States v. Epstein, 2018R01618', described as an investigation relating to enticement of minors for sexual activity.
Multiple travel requests in 2019 show ongoing, active investigation into Epstein, with prosecutors conducting victim interviews in Florida and California.
The emails indicate a pattern of investigators reserving hotel conference rooms to conduct interviews, suggesting formal, off-site evidence gathering.
The correspondence is internal, showing logistical coordination within the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York.
Several individuals are referenced only by initials or single letters (e.g., 'M'), indicating redacted or anonymized names of investigators or prosecutors involved.
